title: Social Work and Contemporary Bioethical Debates
abstract: Abstract This chapter begins with a look at the resurgence of eugenic interest during the 1970s and 1980s, especially in relation to innovations in prenatal testing. While most social work professionals will not be employed as genetic counselors, all need to have a basic understanding of prenatal testing procedures and the difficult decisions that prospective parents may have to make, and this is also discussed. These decisions, moreover, are made within the context of our biopsychosocial view of disability and the perceived future prospects and impact on the family of persons with disabilities. These issues give rise to a number of race- and class-based implications, which are also discussed. Innovations in biogenetics, such as CRISPR and the potential of genetic enhancement procedures, are briefly introduced, as well as the deployment of eugenic policies internationally.
